title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Preface and Definitions
This guide is intended to be a place to host our accumulated institutional knowledge and standard operating procedures regarding the TailWinds project. We‚Äôve already had mild amounts of staff turnover, so the hope is that this will alleviate some of the pain associated with onboarding ‚Äì or ‚Äúre-onboarding‚Äù our current members after periods away from the project.
Inspired by Gavin Fay‚Äôs Lab Manual, this is a living document which everyone should be able to edit.

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Acronyms

BACI

Before-After-Control-Impact design

BAG

Before-After-Gradient design

BSB

black sea bass, Centropristis striata

CBL

Chesapeake Biological Laboratory

EFP

Exempted Fishing Permit

FRM

Fishery Resource Monitoring. One of the three core TailWinds projects. Include FRS #?

IACUC

Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee

LOA

Letter of Authorization/Acknowledgement

MCBP

Maryland Coastal Bays Program

MD DNR

Maryland Department of Natural Resources

MDWEA

Maryland Wind Energy Area, also known as the Maryland Lease Area

MMM

Marine Mammal Monitoring. One of the three core TailWinds projects. Include FRS #?

PAM

Passive acoustic monitoring

RTWB

(Near) Real-Time Whale Buoy. One of the three core TailWinds projects. FRS #?

UMCES

University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science

WHOI

Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Definitions

Console

Where you type commands into R.

Terminal

Command-line interface to the computer. Access in RStudio via Tools > Terminal > New Terminal

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Software

LFDCS

. Allows the detection, characterization, classification, and reporting of marine mammal tonal vocalizations

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Hardware

C-POD

Recording device that consists of a hydrophone and a processor which detects ‚Äútrains‚Äù of echolocation clicks from dolphins and porpoises. Operates in the 20-160 kHz range. Manufactured by Chelonia, Ltd.. Successor to the T-POD, predecessor to the F-POD.

Delphinus

Server located on the UMCES-CBL campus

DMON

Digital acoustic monitoring instrument. Deployed on the RTWB, it is capable of recording and processing audio in near real-time using custom detection algorithms

F-POD

Recording device that consists of a hydrophone and a processor which detects ‚Äútrains‚Äù of echolocation clicks from dolphins and porpoises. Operates in the 20-160 kHz range. Manufactured by Chelonia, Ltd.. Successor to the C-POD.

LS1X

Hydrophone manufactured by Loggerhead, Inc.

Rockhopper

Whale acoustic recording device, owned/operated by Cornell. Successor to the MARU devices.

VR2AR

Fish telemetry receiver with built-in acoustic release device. Operates in the 69 kHz range. Manufactured by Innovasea (formerly named Vemco).

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Source vs Visual editor
Pretty much everything you write for the Guide (and the website) will use Markdown. Some basics are outlined on the Quarto website. Note that if you‚Äôre Googling for something related to Markdown formatting, anything sold as ‚ÄúRMarkdown‚Äù will also work.
All of the different options can be confusing and create a barrier to entry. Enter: the RStudio Visual Markdown editor.
RStudio has a visual editor for markdown documents (also called a ‚Äúwhat-you-see-is-what-you-get‚Äù editor, or WYSIWYG, or ‚Äúwizzy-wig‚Äù, how fun!). You can activate this by clicking ‚ÄúVisual‚Äù in the top left of your code editing pane. Now, R will act as if it were MS Word, allowing you to skip the code and add things with a few clicks. If you‚Äôre curious as to what the markdown code looks like, click ‚ÄúSource‚Äù and it will switch to editing as if you were a coding expert.

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Editing the Guide
Editing the Guide follows the same steps as editing the website, outlined in the next sections. The main difference is that you don‚Äôt run ‚Äúrender website‚Äù, but instead type
quarto publish
into the terminal. This compiles everything and commits the changes to the gh-pages branch. This branch is then used to deploy the website, so don‚Äôt edit that branch.
Note that quarto publish will publish changes from ANY BRANCH, so the branching paradigm doesn‚Äôt necessarily work once that command has been run.

title: TailWinds Guide
text:
Guide editing workflow

Clone the TailWinds Guide repository: https://github.com/Tail-Winds/TailWinds-Guide
If you‚Äôre making relatively minor changes, commit them to the master branch.
If you‚Äôre making substantial changes, create a new branch. You can do this either by:

On GitHub, clicking the box on the top left that says ‚Äúmaster‚Äù and typing in whatever you want to call the new branch, or
Clicking ‚ÄúNew Branch‚Äù in the Git pane in RStudio 

Preview your changes in one document by clicking ‚ÄúRender‚Äù in the editing pane. 
Preview your changes to the whole document by clicking ‚ÄúRender Book‚Äù in the Build pane. 
Commit your changes to your working branch.
If you‚Äôd like to have your changes reviewed, push your commits to GitHub and notify the reviewer (likely Dave or Mike).
If your changes are ready for prime time, enter quarto publish into the Terminal. 
It will ask you to confirm if you want to update the website version of the Guide by typing ‚ÄúYes‚Äù/‚Äúy‚Äù/‚ÄúY‚Äù.

title: 1¬† Quarto
text:
1.1 index.qmd
There should be an index.qmd file for every subsection/folder of the website or guide. Every .qmd file is rendered to a .html file behind the scenes. In website speak, ending a URL in ‚Äúindex.html‚Äù means that your referring to the folder/directory, itself. This means that https://tailwinds.umces.edu/frm/ goes to the same place as https://tailwinds.umces.edu/frm/index.html, for example.

title: 1¬† Quarto
text:
1.2 Building/Rendering
When you click the Render, Preview, or Build buttons, Quarto takes all of your code and renders it to HTML behind the scenes. The website stores these in a folder called _site and the Guide stores them in a folder called _book. These documents are re-written every time you hit that render button, so we‚Äôve set it up so that they are ignored ‚Äì you can see them in the respective .gitignore files.
When we‚Äôre ready for prime time, we‚Äôll run quarto publish gh-pages in the terminal. This compiles any code chunks locally and commits them to the gh-pages branch on GitHub. In the cloud, GitHub takes all of those files, turns the Markdown into HTML, and publishes it to the website.

title: 2¬† YAML
text:
2.1 Spacing and new lines
When looking at YAML, the indentation and new lines are very important. Every time we apply a new argument to a YAML option, it needs to be on a new line, indented under the main argument. HTML YAML options are outlined here. Let‚Äôs assume that we want the document to be exported in HTML format. We‚Äôd write it like this:
format: html
What if we want to include a table of contents? Well, that is an argument to html, so we have to now put html on a new line and indent it under format.
format:
  html: toc
Except toc has an argument of its own ‚Äì we‚Äôll have to put that on a new line and indent it, as well.
format:
  html:
    toc: true
There is a hierarchy in how this is implemented outlined here. I‚Äôll try to plain-English it below.

title: 2¬† YAML
text:
2.2 .yml files

2.2.1 _quarto.yml
.yml files tend to hold the metadata for everything within the folder that it sits. So, the _quarto.yml file in the website and guide‚Äôs root directory dictates how everything in the website/guide is handled.
Go ahead and open the _quarto.yml file and the Guide. See how, in the YAML file, the table of contents is outlined? Now look at the Guide ‚Äì the table of contents reflects this.
Click on a different page in the Guide, and you‚Äôll see that the table of contents is unchanged. This is because the _quarto.yml file controls how all of the pages in the project are rendered.


2.2.2 _metadata.yml
What if there is a specific group of files for which you want to have special rules? This is done by grouping those files in a folder and adding a _metadata.yml file to that folder. It then follows a loose flowchart:

Take all of the options outlined in the main _quarto.yml file.
Add all of the options outlined in the folder/_metadata.yml file.
Where there are different options for the same argument, use the option outlined in the folder/_metadata.yml file.

Now, all of the .qmd files in the specific folder will use those options.

title: 2¬† YAML
text:
2.3 YAML headers
What if you have options specific to an individual document? These are outlined in the space between the two sets of ‚Äú---‚Äù at the top of the document. Now the flowchart for that document becomes:

Take all of the options outlined in the main _quarto.yml file.
Add all of the options outlined in the folder/_metadata.yml file.
Add all of the options outlined in the YAML header of the document (what‚Äôs between the two sets of ---).
Where there are different options for the same argument, first use the option outlined in the document‚Äôs YAML header. If nothing is outlined in the header, use that in the folder/_metadata.yml file.

Open up the source code for the Real-time Whale Buoy page. There are a series of additions regarding where the page‚Äôs audio files are located:
---
title: "Real Time Whale Buoy"
  format:
    html:
      resources:
        - audio
---
This applies specifically to this document. What if, for instance, we wanted that to apply to all documents in the rtwb folder? Well, then we would stick the lines from ‚Äúformat‚Äù to ‚Äú- audio‚Äù into a _metadata.yml file.

title: 2¬† YAML
text:
2.4 Code block YAML
Lastly, you can add YAML in individual code blocks by adding ‚Äú#|‚Äù, followed by the YAML. This takes precedence over the YAML in the document header, _metadata.yml file, and _quarto.yml file.
```{r}
#| eval: false

1+1
```

title: 3¬† Git
text:
3.1 Hansel and Gretel
Imagine you‚Äôre Gretel, running off to Grandma‚Äôs house. You don‚Äôt actually know how to get there, so you leave a trail of breadcrumbs to get back home. If you know where you are and how you‚Äôve gotten there ‚Äì you literally just walked out of your door and down the street ‚Äì you may go a while before dropping a breadcrumb. If you‚Äôre unsure, you might drop bread more frequently.
Each crumb of bread here is a commit. It saves a version of your project that you can jump back to if needed.
However, Hansel is out there too, plowing on ahead and dropping his own crumbs every time you stop to have a snack or a potty break. If he‚Äôs out ahead of you, you can just follow his trail (git pull). What if, at a fork in the road, you went left and he went right? Which trail is correct? This is where git gives up and kicks it back to you to solve.
Happy Git has a walkthrough for some of them, but here is the workflow that Kirsten and I have stumbled on.

title: 3¬† Git
text:
3.2 Can‚Äôt pull

3.2.1 Files may be overwritten
When pulling from Github, you may get a message that says something like ‚ÄúYour local changes to the following files would be overwritten by merge‚Äù. This means that you have files you‚Äôve changed but haven‚Äôt logged a commit for.

‚ÄúRevert‚Äù (send back to the previous breadcrumb/commit) anything in the docs/, _site/, or _book/ folder. As outlined here, they shouldn‚Äôt be tracked (a different issue) and we don‚Äôt need to worry about tracking anything in there.

<add image>

Think about whether you‚Äôve added anything substantial ‚Äì sometimes just one extra space can mean the difference between things going automagically and you having to handle it yourself. To do this, check out the ‚ÄúDiff‚Äù. If it‚Äôs nothing major, revert the file.

<add image>

Commit the rest.
Try to pull again.



3.2.2 Divergent branches
Now your error may say something like ‚ÄúYou have divergent branches and need to specify how to reconcile them.‚Äù

git merge in the terminal?

title: Website and Guide
section: Other websites of which we are covetous
text:
Other websites of which we are covetous

https://rowlrs.marine.rutgers.edu/

title: 4¬† R
text:
4.1 Install R
So, if you don‚Äôt have R installed on your machine, go ahead and download it here, then install. We‚Äôve already run into issues where old versions of the programs we‚Äôre using can mess up how the website renders, so check to see if there‚Äôs a new version of R if you haven‚Äôt updated in a while. The most-recent version of R, version 4.2.2, was issued on Oct 31, 2022. Am I up to date?

R.Version()$version.string

[1] "R version 4.2.2 (2022-10-31 ucrt)"


Yep.

title: 4¬† R
text:
4.2 RStudio
Again, this isn‚Äôt the only program that will run Quarto, I‚Äôm just assuming that it‚Äôs common language at this point. If you get in trouble and need to Google something, chances are that people will already assume you‚Äôre using RStudio. Download by following this link and install.
If you already have RStudio installed, go ahead and check that it‚Äôs the most-recent version (version 2022.12.0.353). Am I up to date?

rstudioapi::versionInfo()$version

Yes.

title: 4¬† R
text:
4.3 Quarto
I‚Äôm fairly certain that RStudio comes with a version of Quarto, the program we‚Äôll use to build the website, installed. However, we need to make sure it is the most up-to-date version. So, go ahead and follow that link and download/install Quarto anyway.
Once you install it, restart R/RStudio. Then go to Tools > Terminal >New Terminal and type
quarto --version
It should return 1.2.313 or greater. If it doesn‚Äôt, let me know!

4.3.1 Quarto extensions
Okay, I got a little cute and put fun little icons linking to everyone‚Äôs various social media presence on the Team page. I‚Äôve found out that now, because I‚Äôve done that, everyone needs to have the cutesy little icon packages downloaded onto their computer. Don‚Äôt worry, they‚Äôre safe (and kind of neat if you want to give them a look).

4.3.1.1 Font Awesome
Font Awesome icons are just what they say they are: some awesome icons! There are literally thousands of them ‚Äì go check them out. They even have a wind turbine, but you have to pay for it. üôÅ
Anyway, we need to install an extension to get them to work with Quarto. Go to Tools > Terminal > New Terminal and type:
quarto install extension quarto-ext/fontawesome
That‚Äôs it!


4.3.1.2 academicons
Academicons are the academic‚Äôs answer to Font Awesome icons. They have icons for Google Scholar, Orcid, Data Dryad, Clarivate (n√©e Web of Science), the list goes on. To install the extension, go to Tools > Terminal > New Terminal and type:
quarto install extension schochastics/academicons

title: 4¬† R
text:
4.4 GitHub
Pop on over to GitHub and sign up for a free account. After you‚Äôre done, let me know and I‚Äôll add you to the TailWinds GitHub organization.

title: 5¬† Installing Git
text:
5.1 Tell Git who you are
We need to tell Git who we are, so that all of our changes can be tied to our name and, later, our GitHub account.
I want to be called ‚ÄúMike O‚ÄôBrien‚Äù, and my GitHub account is tied to my work email, obrien@umces.edu. I would enter:

install.packages('usethis')
usethis::use_git_config(user.name = "Mike O'Brien",
                        user.email = "obrien@umces.edu")

Adjust the above code to your own name/email associated with your GitHub account.

title: 5¬† Installing Git
text:
5.2 Connecting your computer to GitHub
Pay attention to the section on setting up a personal access token (PAT). This won‚Äôt matter at all while your working on the website, but will come back to bite you once you try to send your changes to GitHub. The easiest way is just to follow the instructions on Happy Git and accept the defaults. There are more specifics at that link, but the steps more or less look like this:

Download the usethis package and run the create_github_token function


install.packages('usethis')
usethis::create_github_token()


This will open a website. Click ‚ÄúGenerate token‚Äù.
KEEP THIS WINDOW OPEN. It will give you a gibberish string that is basically your computer-to-computer password. Again, for now, KEEP THIS WINDOW OPEN.
Type the following into R:


gitcreds::gitcreds_set()


Copy the PAT from the window you kept open and paste it into R. If everything worked as it‚Äôs supposed to, you should be able to send your changes to GitHub when the time comes.

title: 6¬† Clone
text:
6.1 Aside: Forking
Cloning someone else‚Äôs GitHub repository is called ‚Äúforking‚Äù. This makes a complete copy of the repository and places it into your GitHub account. You can then use the rest of the steps in this guide to make adjustments to their code.
Generally, when you wish to contribute to someone else‚Äôs package/code/repository, you:

Fork it to your GitHub account,
Clone the forked repository to your computer,
Create a new branch (see the next step in this guide),
Commit your changes to the new branch,
Push them back to GitHub,
Open a pull request for the original repository‚Äôs maintainer to pull your changes into their version of the repository.

title: 7¬† Branch
text:
7.1 Making a branch
Note that these instructions are intentionally redundant to the section on making a branch to edit the Guide. You can make a new branch either by:

On GitHub, clicking the box on the top left that says ‚Äúmaster‚Äù and typing in whatever you want to call the new branch,
Clicking ‚ÄúNew Branch‚Äù in the Git pane in RStudio

If you used method #1, pull the GitHub repository. The new branch will appear on the right side of the Git pane. If you used method #2, the branch should automatically be pushed to GitHub and RStudio will switch to this branch.

title: 8¬† Write
text:
Now we‚Äôre going to create or edit Quarto (.qmd) files for the desired page.
The Quarto website has really thorough guides on how to do this. Slava and I are also on call via Slack!
Generally:

Click the ‚ÄúPull‚Äù button in the Git tab. This will download any changes that have made to the website that you don‚Äôt have.
Go to File > New File > Quarto Document to make a new page.
Write whatever you want to go on the page.
If you want the file to show up on the website‚Äôs navigation bar, edit the _quarto.yml file ‚Äì this serves as the website‚Äôs map. Feel free to skip this step if you don‚Äôt want people to navigate to the page just yet. This is similar to the current page you‚Äôre on ‚Äì you can access directly through the URL, but not by clicking to it.
If you want to take a quick glimpse at what the page you are editing will look like, click the ‚ÄúRender‚Äù button at the top of the editing pane, between the magnifying glass and cog. This will not change any other page or the locations to which the navigation bar points you.
If you made changes to the navigation bar go to Build > Preview Site. This will convert everything to HTML behind the scenes.

title: 9¬† Commit
text:
Saving a version of all of the files in your repository is called a ‚Äúcommit‚Äù. To do so, click the ‚ÄúCommit‚Äù button in the Git pane. It will open another window showing you all of the files that have changed and their difference from previous versions: green means that something has been added and red means that something has been removed.
Click the little box in the ‚ÄúStaged‚Äù column next to a file or files, then type a little note as to what you‚Äôve changed in the ‚ÄúCommit message‚Äù box. Then click the ‚ÄúCommit‚Äù button et voil√†! These frozen snapshots of differences in your code or text will be stored on your computer and can be accessed later if necessary.
From Happy Git:

The daily workflow is probably not dramatically different from what you do currently. You work in the usual way, writing R scripts or authoring reports in LaTeX or R Markdown. But instead of only saving individual files, periodically you make a commit, which takes a snapshot of all the files in the entire project. If you have ever versioned a file by adding your initials or the date, you have effectively made a commit, albeit only for a single file. It is a version that is significant to you and that you might want to inspect or revert to later. Periodically, you push commits to GitHub. This is like sharing a document with colleagues on DropBox or sending it out as an email attachment. By pushing to GitHub, you make your work and all your accumulated progress accessible to others.

Don‚Äôt be afraid to ‚Äúcommit‚Äù changes early and often ‚Äì think of these as breadcrumbs leading you back from where you came. If you‚Äôre confident you can get back there, no need to commit everything. If you‚Äôre trailblazing through uncharted territory, you probably want to commit more often.

title: 10¬† Pull
text:
No, we‚Äôre not shooting skeet.
There will probably come a time when someone has made changes to the website between the time that you last downloaded things from GitHub and now. If you try to send your changes (commits) back up to GitHub, it will stop and let you know that things have changed.
In order to get ahead of this, click the ‚ÄúPull‚Äù button. This will pull the changes from GitHub onto your computer. Hopefully, it‚Äôll go ahead and merge everything together for you. If it can‚Äôt ‚Äì usually when you have edited the same lines that someone else has ‚Äì it will combine the two versions of the files and ask you to sort it out. This usually means opening the files and making an executive decision about what text/code you wish to keep.

title: 11¬† Push
text:
Take a deep breath, like Lamaze for your code.
Now that everything is in line, compile the website one more time via Build > Render, commit changes, and click the ‚ÄúPush‚Äù button. This pushes all of the changes you‚Äôve logged on your computer (via commits) to GitHub. If you‚Äôve been editing the master branch, this will automatically change the website.
If you‚Äôve been editing in your own branch, things are less stressful. A new branch is your own little sandbox ‚Äì nothing will get added to the website before it‚Äôs approved by Mike. To get that done, you need to open a pull request (next section).
If you get an error that looks like this‚Ä¶
remote: Support for password authentication was removed on August 13, 2021. Please use a personal access token instead.
remote: Please see https://github.blog/2020-12-15-token-authentication-requirements-for-git-operations/ for more information.
fatal: Authentication failed for 'https://github.com/OWNER/REPO.git/'
‚Ä¶you need to let GitHub know that you‚Äôre allowed to make changes to your account. Refer back to the section on installing Git.

title: 12¬† Pull request
text:
12.1 Open a pull request
To open a pull request:\

Go to the website‚Äôs GitHub page
Select your branch by clicking the button that says ‚Äúmain‚Äù on the left just above all of the code.
There will be a button that says ‚ÄúCompare & pull request‚Äù. Click it.
This opens a ‚ÄúOpen a pull request‚Äù page. Go ahead and make a note about what this is going to do and click ‚ÄúCreate pull request‚Äù.
At this point, you and Mike will start to have a conversation about anything that needs to be adjusted before going live on the website. Hopefully the conversation will be short, and the request can be directly merged!
After thr pull request is accepted, GitHub will offer to delete the branch. As we want branches to target singular issues/tasks, it‚Äôs good to go ahead and let this happen. Don‚Äôt worry, all of the changes you‚Äôve made are cataloged in commits, which have now been tacked onto the main branch!

title: 12¬† Pull request
text:
12.2 Prune a deleted branch
So you‚Äôve created a branch, made some edits, and had your pull request accepted. Now, you have a branch that was likely deleted on GitHub but is still hanging around on your computer. We can ‚Äúprune‚Äù this branch by running the following in the Terminal, assuming that ‚Äúbranch-to-delete‚Äù is the name of the branch you want to delete:
git branch -d branch-to-delete
git fetch -p
